title: How to Cook Salmon Fillet

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 400℉ (200℃).
steps.description: Set your oven’s temperature and wait for the appliance to reach the proper heat. Although it may be tempting to start cooking the fish as soon as possible, it’s important to let the oven hit the desired temperature first. If you set it to something lower, there’s a chance that the salmon won’t cook properly.

steps.headline: Prepare a baking sheet with shallow sides by covering it with nonstick aluminum foil.
steps.description: Make sure that the foil is covering the entire surface of the pan, or at least the parts that the salmon will be sitting on. If necessary, use scissors to trim the foil so that it fits the pan exactly. Coat the pan with nonstick cooking spray if you don't have aluminum foil on hand.

steps.headline: Season the fillets with mustard, salt and pepper.
steps.description: Spread 3 tablespoons (44 mL) of Dijon mustard evenly over the surface of each fillet before topping the pieces with ¼ cup (25 g) of breadcrumbs and equal amounts of salt and pepper. Help the different seasonings stick together by drizzling 0.25 cups (59 mL) of melted butter over the 4 fillets. If the salmon fillets have skin on them, make sure the skin is touching the line of foil on the pan. Make sure that the fillets are all spaced evenly. If you’d like to try preparing your salmon with some different flavor combinations, try dill butter or lemon relish instead.

steps.headline: Transfer the fillets to the baking sheet.
steps.description: Move each piece of salmon onto the prepared baking tray, leaving at least 1 inch (2.5 cm) of space between them. If the salmon fillets have skin on them, have the skin be touching the line of foil on the pan.

steps.headline: Bake the fillets for 15 minutes.
steps.description: Place the baking sheet on the middle rack in the oven and wait for the salmon to cook completely. When it’s finished cooking, you should be able to easily split the salmon with a fork. If the fillets don’t seem cooked, place them back in the oven for 2-minute increments. Check the pieces periodically with a meat thermometer, and make sure that the meat is at least 145 °F (63 °C).

steps.headline: Remove the fillets from the oven and serve them immediately.
steps.description: Pair the fillets with a softer side dish, like roasted potatoes. If you’re aiming to create a more savory meal, include a vegetable like asparagus instead. Feel free to squeeze some fresh lemon juice over the meal for an extra zing. While the fillets don’t have to be eaten right away, they’ll taste delicious coming fresh from the oven. Refrigerate the fillets by putting them on a plate and wrapping them in plastic. Make sure that each piece has cooled before doing this. Your salmon will stay fresh for about 3 days!

steps.headline: Place a skillet on your heated cooking surface for 3 minutes.
steps.description: Find a large, wide skillet that can hold four 6-oz salmon fillets, and place it on the stovetop. Once the pan is in place, set the stovetop burner to a medium heat level. To allow the salmon to be cooked as evenly as possible, wait at least 3 minutes before adding any salmon to the pan. Preheating the skillet allows your fillets to start cooking instantly once they’re placed on the stovetop.

steps.headline: Drizzle some olive oil over each fillet before putting them in the skillet.
steps.description: Pour 0.5 tablespoons (7.4 mL) of oil over each piece of salmon to ensure that both sides are coated and ready to be cooked. Once both sides of each fillet are lightly covered in oil, put all 4 pieces into the skillet. Since you’ve coated the fillets with oil, you don’t need to worry about greasing the skillet.

steps.headline: Sear the fillet for 3 minutes on high heat.
steps.description: Let the salmon cook on the stovetop for several minutes. At this point, add in any capers and additional spices you’d like to include. If you want to add some kick to your fillets, try seasoning the salmon with cumin or chili powder for a spicier touch. Cinnamon, mustard powder, and paprika are also great seasoning alternatives.

steps.headline: Flip over the salmon and let it sit for 5 more minutes.
steps.description: Cook the other side of the salmon fillet by turning it over in the pan. If desired, continue adding seasoning to the opposite side of the fillet as well. After 5 minutes, try flaking the salmon with a fork to see if it’s finished cooking. Additionally, wait for the seared salmon fillets to look brown before you remove them.

steps.headline: Serve the salmon fillets immediately after they’re done cooking.
steps.description: Slide each piece of salmon onto a plate, and garnish all of them with a piece of lemon. To complement the meal, add some roasted vegetables as a side dish. If you’re preparing the salmon for a more formal occasion consider making a roasted vegetable purée instead. Don’t worry if you don’t eat all of your pan-seared salmon at once. Place the leftovers in an airtight container and refrigerate them for up to 3 days.

steps.headline: Coat the salmon fillet with salt, lemon pepper, and garlic powder.
steps.description: Sprinkle a pinch of each ingredient over the fillet, covering both sides evenly. If you’d prefer your fillets to have a stronger flavor, feel free to use more salt, lemon pepper, and garlic powder as you see fit. Try to season the edges of the fillet as well. As a rule of thumb, a pinch can range between 1/8 and 1/16 of a teaspoon.

steps.headline: Create your marinade by mixing soy sauce, brown sugar, water, and oil together.
steps.description: Combine ⅓ cup (75 mL) of soy sauce, ⅓ cup (67.5 g) of brown sugar, ⅓ cup (79 mL) of water, and ¼ cup (59 mL) of vegetable oil in a bowl and mix them together thoroughly. Continue mixing until the sugar dissolves into the other ingredients, and the marinade is smooth. For easier stirring, try mixing the liquid ingredients together first before adding in the brown sugar.

steps.headline: Refrigerate the fillets and marinade in a plastic bag for 2 hours.
steps.description: Slide the fish into a sealable bag, ensuring that there’s enough room for the sugar and soy sauce mixture. Once all the fillets are accounted for in the bag, pour the marinade over the seasoned fillets. After pouring, seal the bag completely before flipping it over, allowing both sides of the fillet to be covered. Finally, set the bag in the refrigerator and let the fillets chill in the marinade for 2 hours. If you have a lot of salmon fillets, consider marinating them in more than 1 bag. Split the marinade up accordingly when you go to coat and refrigerate the fillets.

steps.headline: Preheat your grill to 350 °F (177 °C) and drizzle the grate with oil.
steps.description: Turn on your grill and let it heat up. If your grill doesn’t have a temperature gauge, hover your hand about 3 inches (7.6 cm) above the grate. Count how many seconds it takes for your palm to feel the heat of the grill. For salmon fillets, wait until it takes about 6-7 seconds for your hand to feel warm. Once the grill is preheated, sprinkle some vegetable oil over the surface to make the salmon fillets easier to flip. If you can feel the heat within 1-5 seconds, then the grill is too hot.

steps.headline: Grill each side of the fillet for 6-8 minutes.
steps.description: Space the fillets evenly on the grill surface and let them cook for at least 6 minutes before flipping them over. Continue flipping as needed, and remove the salmon from the grill when it can be flaked with a fork. If you’re using fillets with the skin still on, be sure to start cooking with skin facing up. When flipping fillets to have the skin side facing down, feel free to lower the temperature of the grill.

steps.headline: Serve the fillets while they’re still warm.
steps.description: Give the fillets a few minutes to cool down once they’re removed from the grill. Try pairing your salmon with some light, refreshing side dishes. An array of roasted vegetables like carrots and sweet potatoes taste great with the fillets, as do fresh beans and salad. Don’t worry if you can’t eat your fillets all once. Instead, put them in a plastic container and refrigerate them for up to 3 days after grilling.
